quotes.topic_title: Introduction and why teams miss the basics
quotes.text: We would have a conversation with founders, you're saying like, "Gosh, I'm almost embarrassed to ask this question, but who exactly is your target customer?" And three co-founders have three different answers.
quotes.speaker: Jake Knapp
quotes.context: Highlights a common early-stage failure mode: teams think they’re aligned on fundamentals but aren’t—even on the target customer.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and why teams miss the basics
quotes.text: After these hundreds of teams that we've worked with, we've seen that there's one failure mode, which is they don't know what that set of basics are. Then there's this other failure mode where they never test it.
quotes.speaker: John Zeratsky
quotes.context: A crisp two-part diagnostic for why teams fail: missing the basics, or failing to validate them.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and why teams miss the basics
quotes.text: The very beginning of your project, we recommend this kind of crazy idea that you clear your calendar. So the core team come together for 10 hours roughly and go through a sequence of activities so that we can make all of the key decisions together.
quotes.speaker: Jake Knapp
quotes.context: Actionable process guidance for the Foundation Sprint: timebox alignment and decision-making early with the core team.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and why teams miss the basics
quotes.text: One phenomenon we've seen when teams are building things really quickly with AI is that the more AI-generated or assisted they are, the more generic they tend to turn out. Put yourself in a situation where you can slow down and do some hard thinking, some deep thinking about what's actually going to make your product unique. Going fast can actually slow you down in the long run.
quotes.speaker: John Zeratsky
quotes.context: Counterintuitive warning that speed—especially with AI—can reduce differentiation and create long-run drag without deliberate thinking.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Brex knows that nearly 40% of startups fail because they run out of cash, so they built a banking experience that focuses on helping founders get more from every dollar.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Highlights a concrete failure-rate data point and ties it to a practical focus area: cash efficiency and runway extension.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: It's a stark difference from traditional banking options that leave a startup's cash sitting idle while chipping away at it with fees.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A memorable framing that challenges the default assumption that standard banking is “good enough” for startups.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Integrations are mission critical for AI for two reasons.
quotes.speaker: Brandon Foo
quotes.context: Introduces a simple two-part mental model for why integrations matter in AI products.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: First, AI products need contacts from their customers business data, such as Google Drive files, Slack messages, or CRM records.
quotes.speaker: Brandon Foo
quotes.context: Gives concrete examples of the data sources AI products must connect to in order to be useful.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: We believe product teams should focus engineering efforts and competitive advantages, not integrations.
quotes.speaker: Brandon Foo
quotes.context: A prioritization principle for engineering teams: invest in differentiation rather than commodity integration work.

quotes.topic_title: Foundation Sprint origin from Design Sprint
quotes.text: We cleared our calendars for the week, and we created a prototype of this, this thing because we decided, look, we're never going to get anywhere.
quotes.speaker: Jake Knapp
quotes.context: Highlights the high-leverage tactic of calendar-clearing to force focus and momentum toward a tangible artifact.

quotes.topic_title: Foundation Sprint origin from Design Sprint
quotes.text: Perfection is not working.
quotes.speaker: Jake Knapp
quotes.context: A contrarian reminder that perfect docs/pitches/designs can stall progress compared to building something real.

quotes.topic_title: Foundation Sprint origin from Design Sprint
quotes.text: Forget it. We're just going to build something and put it in people's hands, put it in our fellow Googlers hands.
quotes.speaker: Jake Knapp
quotes.context: Actionable shift from persuasion-by-artifacts (PRDs, pitches) to learning-by-exposure (hands-on prototype).

quotes.topic_title: Foundation Sprint origin from Design Sprint
quotes.text: The notion that maybe you could repeat that and recreate that is what led me to create the Design Sprint.
quotes.speaker: Jake Knapp
quotes.context: Captures the core methodology insight: turning a one-off “best week” into a repeatable process.

quotes.topic_title: Foundation Sprint origin from Design Sprint
quotes.text: So across five days, it's map, sketch, decide, prototype, and test, one big focal point for each day.
quotes.speaker: Jake Knapp
quotes.context: A concise, reusable 5-day sprint framework practitioners can directly apply to structure high-risk work.

quotes.topic_title: Why a new sprint for pre-seed teams
quotes.text: One of our goals, probably our biggest goal for starting our own VC firm was that we wanted to be able to focus on just the kinds of companies and the stage of company-building that was the most fun to us, but also was where we thought we could have the biggest impact.
quotes.speaker: John Zeratsky
quotes.context: A practical lens for choosing where to focus: optimize for both enjoyment and maximum leverage/impact.

quotes.topic_title: Why a new sprint for pre-seed teams
quotes.text: But when we started investing in truly pre-seed, sometimes inception stage, pre-product, pre-revenue, pre-everything companies, there was this piece missing at the beginning of that process.
quotes.speaker: John Zeratsky
quotes.context: Highlights a counterintuitive gap: the earliest-stage teams often lack prerequisites that later-stage methods assume.

quotes.topic_title: Why a new sprint for pre-seed teams
quotes.text: And it was things like, what is the problem you're solving and who's the ideal customer? How are you different than what's in the market today? Who are your actual competitors?
quotes.speaker: John Zeratsky
quotes.context: A concrete checklist of foundational questions to align on before running execution-oriented processes like sprints.

quotes.topic_title: Why a new sprint for pre-seed teams
quotes.text: Hey, we need to create a new sprint method, something that is really targeted for the very beginning of these big new projects." And so that was what led us to create the Foundation Sprint at Character Capital in 2021, 2022.
quotes.speaker: John Zeratsky
quotes.context: Introduces a new methodology (Foundation Sprint) designed specifically for pre-seed alignment and clarity.

quotes.topic_title: Foundation Sprint structure and timeboxing
quotes.text: We recommend this kind of crazy idea that you clear your schedule, you clear your calendar.
quotes.speaker: Jake Knapp
quotes.context: Sets the counterintuitive premise that high-leverage project starts require total calendar clearance, not incremental meetings.

quotes.topic_title: Foundation Sprint structure and timeboxing
quotes.text: And during those 10 hours, we're going to go through a sequence of activities, very highly scripted sequence of activities so that we can make all of the key decisions together and identify the basics of the project, what's going to differentiate us in the marketplace, and what's the best approach or implementation path.
quotes.speaker: Jake Knapp
quotes.context: Defines the Foundation Sprint as a scripted decision-making framework to align on strategy, differentiation, and execution path quickly.

quotes.topic_title: Foundation Sprint structure and timeboxing
quotes.text: Once you've got that founding hypothesis, then you're going to go and do design sprints, and we recommend you clear the calendar for two to three weeks at least, so you have the chance to be wrong about your hypothesis.
quotes.speaker: Jake Knapp
quotes.context: Turns validation into a timeboxed practice: clear weeks to run experiments explicitly designed to falsify the hypothesis.

quotes.topic_title: Foundation Sprint structure and timeboxing
quotes.text: So at the big picture, it's going to be anywhere from 10 hours to three to four weeks.
quotes.speaker: Jake Knapp
quotes.context: Provides a concrete end-to-end timebox for the methodology, making it easier to plan and commit organizationally.

quotes.topic_title: Foundation Sprint structure and timeboxing
quotes.text: In the 10 hours, it's a chance to get clarity about the core of your strategy, which is something that teams will often go months without really nailing down.
quotes.speaker: Jake Knapp
quotes.context: Highlights the ROI claim: compressing months of strategic ambiguity into a 10-hour structured sprint.

quotes.topic_title: Three phases: basics, differentiation, approach
quotes.text: So there are three phases to the Foundation Sprint. First phase is the basics, second phase is differentiation, and the third phase is the approach to the project.
quotes.speaker: Jake Knapp
quotes.context: A simple 3-part structure practitioners can use to run a focused, repeatable “Foundation Sprint.”

quotes.topic_title: Three phases: basics, differentiation, approach
quotes.text: So the first phase, the basics, as I mentioned, that's identifying who's your customer, what problem are you solving for the customer? What's the competition for solving that problem? How do they solve it today? And what are the alternatives? How else do people solve this? What are the workarounds?
quotes.speaker: Jake Knapp
quotes.context: A concrete checklist of foundational questions that surfaces misalignment and clarifies what you’re actually building.

quotes.topic_title: Three phases: basics, differentiation, approach
quotes.text: Those are really almost embarrassingly simple things to answer. But when we do this with a team and everybody's answering, proposing their answer to each question, we see everybody's got a different perspective.
quotes.speaker: Jake Knapp
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reminder that “obvious” basics still hide major team disagreement until explicitly written down.

quotes.topic_title: Three phases: basics, differentiation, approach
quotes.text: If we solve this problem for this customer with this approach, we think they're going to choose it over the competitors because of differentiator one and differentiator two.
quotes.speaker: Jake Knapp
quotes.context: A “Mad Libs” founding-hypothesis sentence teams can use to crystallize assumptions into something testable.

quotes.topic_title: Three phases: basics, differentiation, approach
quotes.text: And it's almost silly how simple this thing is, but really powerful for founders to have that clarity about, okay, here it all is in one sentence. Now let's go test and make sure this is true.
quotes.speaker: Jake Knapp
quotes.context: Emphasizes turning strategy into a single testable hypothesis rather than a long, vague plan.

quotes.topic_title: Example setup: Latchet and Character Labs
quotes.text: But essentially this is kind of an accelerator-like program that we run at Character Capital where we invest in a group of companies at the same time, and we run them through that process that we were just describing, where we start with a Foundation Sprint, and then it's going to be a sequence of three design sprints after that so that they're testing and refining that hypothesis.
quotes.speaker: Jake Knapp
quotes.context: A concrete, repeatable sprint sequence (Foundation Sprint + three design sprints) for rapidly testing and refining a startup hypothesis.

quotes.topic_title: Example setup: Latchet and Character Labs
quotes.text: And the progress you can see in those three and a half, four weeks, it's phenomenal.
quotes.speaker: Jake Knapp
quotes.context: A specific timebox claim that underscores how much momentum structured sprints can create in under a month.

quotes.topic_title: Example setup: Latchet and Character Labs
quotes.text: Their instinct is to write code, it's to build software.
quotes.speaker: John Zeratsky
quotes.context: Highlights a common builder bias that can derail early-stage product discovery if left unchecked.

quotes.topic_title: Example setup: Latchet and Character Labs
quotes.text: we would be encouraging them not to write code right away, to take this time to clarify the differentiation, the structure of what they're building, and to validate that with customers before they went all in on building a particular approach.
quotes.speaker: John Zeratsky
quotes.context: Actionable guidance to delay coding in favor of clarifying differentiation and validating with customers first.

quotes.topic_title: Example setup: Latchet and Character Labs
quotes.text: eventually they saw how much more valuable it was to work in this way versus just diving right into building something.
quotes.speaker: John Zeratsky
quotes.context: A counterintuitive lesson that disciplined pre-build validation can outperform immediately shipping code.

quotes.topic_title: Basics phase mechanics: work alone together
quotes.text: we're using this tactic that we call work alone together.
quotes.speaker: Jake Knapp
quotes.context: Names a repeatable collaboration tactic that reduces groupthink by combining individual thinking with shared alignment.

quotes.topic_title: Basics phase mechanics: work alone together
quotes.text: the note and vote is this method where everyone's in silence, in this case both Chris and James, but if you have a team of seven, it's all seven people be working in silence, writing down their own answers to this question, who's the most important customer or who are all the different kind of customers we might consider? Writing down multiple answers.
quotes.speaker: Jake Knapp
quotes.context: Gives a concrete, step-by-step method (silent ideation + multiple options) teams can run immediately to generate better inputs before discussion.

quotes.topic_title: Basics phase mechanics: work alone together
quotes.text: one person who's designated as the decider, usually it's going to be the CEO of the startup, but it could be in some cases, maybe it's the chief product officer, whatever, however they decide to do it. But one person's going to say, "Okay, this is our decision for now, and now we're going to move on."
quotes.speaker: Jake Knapp
quotes.context: Introduces a clear decision-rights mechanism to prevent stalls and keep momentum during early alignment work.

quotes.topic_title: Basics phase mechanics: work alone together
quotes.text: by doing this and using silence and using structure and then having a designated decision-making process, we can move through a lot of conversations very quickly and save some of that energy that it requires to make the decisions that matter most.
quotes.speaker: Jake Knapp
quotes.context: Explains the payoff: structured process conserves team energy for high-leverage decisions instead of draining it on endless debate.

quotes.topic_title: Basics phase mechanics: work alone together
quotes.text: realistically, if you're delivering a solution, you need to stand out from all of those.
quotes.speaker: Jake Knapp
quotes.context: A practical differentiation reminder: competitors include not just direct products but also alternatives like in-person sales and art fairs.

quotes.topic_title: Why basics matter: surprises and alignment
quotes.text: I think the moment where you immediately start to see value is when everyone on the team is writing down their answers to these questions. And then people put their heads up and look at what everyone else has written and they realize, "Oh, that's not what I said," or "I didn't think of that one." Or, "Gosh."
quotes.speaker: Jake Knapp
quotes.context: A practical method for surfacing misalignment fast: write independently first, then compare to reveal hidden assumption gaps.

quotes.topic_title: Why basics matter: surprises and alignment
quotes.text: I think that problem can be really interesting because when teams sit down and think about it, it is often less clear than they thought what the actual problem is. Like, "Wait, what problem do our customers really have that we're solving for them?"
quotes.speaker: John Zeratsky
quotes.context: A reminder that “the problem” is often fuzzy until forced into explicit articulation—an early diagnostic for product work.

quotes.topic_title: Why basics matter: surprises and alignment
quotes.text: I think competition can be sort of an aha moment when they start to think beyond just what are the other startups in this space? If this is an important problem, your customer's probably already solving it somehow. It may be a workaround, it may be an alternative, it may not be a direct competitor, but if it's worth solving, they probably have some way of dealing with it today. And what is that?
quotes.speaker: John Zeratsky
quotes.context: Expands the competitive set to include workarounds/alternatives, which is crucial for understanding real user behavior and differentiation.

quotes.topic_title: Why basics matter: surprises and alignment
quotes.text: So they really have to dig deep and figure out what can we do that nobody else is capable of doing? And...
quotes.speaker: John Zeratsky
quotes.context: A differentiation prompt tailored to startups: focus on unique capabilities rather than trying to match incumbents on scale or distribution.

quotes.topic_title: Why basics matter: surprises and alignment
quotes.text: We run more foundation sprints with startups than we do design sprints at this point.
quotes.speaker: John Zeratsky
quotes.context: A concrete signal of priority/ROI: establishing fundamentals is now considered more valuable than jumping straight into design sprint execution.

quotes.topic_title: Differentiation phase and the two-by-two
quotes.text: We have limited working memory and we've got to have the right stuff in there when we're going to make a big decision, when we're going to think hard about a certain problem or question, it's important to have the right context fresh at hand.
quotes.speaker: Jake Knapp
quotes.context: A practical mental model for why the sprint sequence matters: you’re “booting” the right context before making high-stakes product decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Differentiation phase and the two-by-two
quotes.text: It's crucial then that a product has a clear promise that it makes, and that promise is radically differentiated from the alternatives and that that promise is strong enough that you'll try it and then that the product delivers on that promise.
quotes.speaker: Jake Knapp
quotes.context: Defines differentiation as an end-to-end promise (attention → trial → delivery), not just a positioning statement.

quotes.topic_title: Differentiation phase and the two-by-two
quotes.text: we want you to be really clear on your promise, not the promise you're making to investors about this technology and what's special about the technology or what's special about the market opportunity, but what the customer at the center.
quotes.speaker: Jake Knapp
quotes.context: A contrarian reminder to anchor differentiation in customer value rather than investor/tech narratives.

quotes.topic_title: Differentiation phase and the two-by-two
quotes.text: So we want to have a way of looking at the world that puts all of the competitors into Loserville.
quotes.speaker: Jake Knapp
quotes.context: A memorable heuristic for building a two-by-two: choose axes that make your offering uniquely top-right and competitors fall into the “L-shape.”

quotes.topic_title: Differentiation phase and the two-by-two
quotes.text: Can you deliver on it and do customers care and believe that that matters to them? If both of those things are true, you have a really compelling promise.
quotes.speaker: Jake Knapp
quotes.context: A simple viability test for differentiators: feasibility (deliver) plus desirability/credibility (customers care and believe).

quotes.topic_title: Why most two-by-twos are wrong
quotes.text: And I think the reason why usually these two by two diagrams feel like this is just consultant baloney. This is just like who... It's because maybe one person makes this chart and they do it quickly because they needed to slide for the slide deck and the audience they're considering, maybe it's investors.
quotes.speaker: Jake Knapp
quotes.context: Calls out the common failure mode of 2x2s being created as performative deckware rather than a decision tool.

quotes.topic_title: Why most two-by-twos are wrong
quotes.text: And so often these describe technology or they describe the market opportunity, they don't talk about the customer's perspective.
quotes.speaker: Jake Knapp
quotes.context: A practical diagnostic for improving positioning artifacts: ensure axes reflect customer perspective, not internal/market abstractions.

quotes.topic_title: Why most two-by-twos are wrong
quotes.text: And the other thing is that they're not proven. There's no evidence behind the fact that these are true.
quotes.speaker: Jake Knapp
quotes.context: Highlights validation as the missing ingredient—differentiators should be evidence-backed, not asserted.

quotes.topic_title: Why most two-by-twos are wrong
quotes.text: And so if you do all of those things and you do it at the beginning of the project, we think this has the potential, when we've seen it becomes this, well, this guiding light, here's the North Star. We need to deliver on this. This is what we have to create. And that helps you make decisions all the way through your product development cycle.
quotes.speaker: Jake Knapp
quotes.context: A methodology: do the 2x2 early with team alignment + testing so it becomes a durable North Star for product decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Why most two-by-twos are wrong
quotes.text: The problem is that all of this stuff gets backgrounded. It's something we've thought about a bit. We assume we're on the same page, we assume we're going to deliver something, but then business as usual happens, we build a product, we get kind of more interested in the technology and delivering that, and we end up trying to sell it to customers at the end.
quotes.speaker: Jake Knapp
quotes.context: Warns against a common trap—defaulting to tech-first execution and postponing customer-relevant differentiation until launch.

quotes.topic_title: Classic differentiators list and pricing discussion
quotes.text: Anyway, the standard classic differentiators where we start, they are fast to slow, smart to not so smart, easy to use to hard to use, free to expensive, focused to one size fits all, simple to complicated and integrated to siloed.
quotes.speaker: Jake Knapp
quotes.context: A compact, practical starter framework teams can use to score and discuss differentiation beyond just price/speed.

quotes.topic_title: Classic differentiators list and pricing discussion
quotes.text: But it also starts to make the team comfortable with this notion of differentiation. And again, we want to make differentiation something that all of the co-founders or core team can participate in. It's not just the job of the person writing the pitch deck. It's not just the job of the marketer or the salesperson, but we're getting everybody's perspective in on it and this is a great warm up activity before we start to write our own custom differentiators.
quotes.speaker: Jake Knapp
quotes.context: Actionable advice for making differentiation a cross-functional exercise, using “classic differentiators” as a warm-up before custom axes.

quotes.topic_title: Classic differentiators list and pricing discussion
quotes.text: I think price is rarely the most important differentiator.
quotes.speaker: John Zeratsky
quotes.context: A contrarian reminder that competing on price is usually not the strongest or most durable positioning strategy.

quotes.topic_title: Classic differentiators list and pricing discussion
quotes.text: Where I think pricing has become a really clear advantage for some companies is those that are leveraging AI to solve problems that were previously unsolvable with software. So we have a company that we invested in called BindWell and they use AI to design precision pesticides.
quotes.speaker: John Zeratsky
quotes.context: A concrete example of when price can become a durable edge: AI unlocking fundamentally new cost structures (e.g., AI-designed pesticides).

quotes.topic_title: Classic differentiators list and pricing discussion
quotes.text: If teams are through and they're being really realistic about how they stack up against the competition, it's normal and natural to find that you're not going to be the best on all these differentiators.
quotes.speaker: John Zeratsky
quotes.context: A useful positioning principle: realism about tradeoffs helps teams focus on a small number of winnable, high-value differentiators.

quotes.topic_title: Being honest: you can’t win on everything
quotes.text: If teams are through and they're being really realistic about how they stack up against the competition, it's normal and natural to find that you're not going to be the best on all these differentiators.
quotes.speaker: John Zeratsky
quotes.context: Encourages teams to assess competitive positioning honestly and accept that they won’t lead on every dimension.

quotes.topic_title: Being honest: you can’t win on everything
quotes.text: And that is really helpful for creating clarity in your positioning and in your marketing because you're not going to show a feature checklist chart that says you're better at everything than every competitor.
quotes.speaker: John Zeratsky
quotes.context: Warns against the common “better at everything” marketing trap and ties honesty to clearer positioning.

quotes.topic_title: Being honest: you can’t win on everything
quotes.text: But if you can drive home one or two things that your customers really care about and that you can be radically better at, it's going to improve your chances of winning and finding product market fit.
quotes.speaker: John Zeratsky
quotes.context: Provides a practical focus strategy: pick 1–2 customer-valued axes where you can be radically better to win.

quotes.topic_title: Being honest: you can’t win on everything
quotes.text: And we find that going through this process where you're not just thinking about one differentiator at a time or you're not trying to win on all of them, but you're looking across this scale of options and you're being just really honest about where you stack up can both point you in the right direction in terms of what you will win on, but also can give you the comfort to say, hey, it's okay if we're not better than every single company on every single one of these things.
quotes.speaker: John Zeratsky
quotes.context: Describes a comparative scoring process across multiple dimensions to identify where you can win—and normalize tradeoffs.
